page.title: 09Darenth Wood, Chalky Zone
page.content: Continuing our walk to the base of the slope, wood anemones, dog's mercury and bluebells, soon to be in flower, were thriving. We crossed the ancient track marked by an earthbank and ditch, and looked at the pollarded trees serving as an ownership boundary marker. Beyond we moved into the calcareous hornbeam/sessile oak community. Loose patches of Thamnium alopecurum, a moss forming tight green ball, unattached to the floor were very noticeable. Butchers' broom was common, also the upright leaves of stinking iris. We stopped to look at the dark evergreen leaves of Daphne laureola, some field maple stools and festoons of clematis stems. On through the newly coppiced area we went to see the large wild service tree and came across some parasite toothwort.
